body:
I think the discussion can happen fine as long as it is in the public channels. This PR is also a public channel. This is an API that could be used either way and wonâ€™t block your code change. 

I have already listed my technical reasonings. As I said, I am open to merge it in but there are also reason why not to, so please at least discuss these points
@kevinthesun Have added the test case.
Great looks good, thanks!
Sorry about the slow response, been very busy :)
ping @kevinthesun
Thank you @FrozenGene for fixing this. This is now merged.
some nits, looks good in general, please see if you can fix
Please fix @icemelon9 's comment and retrigger the CI. this is almost ready to be merged
Thanks @tqchen

Thanks for your comments and open mind.

My approach to this PR is from a user of NNVM API coming from its usage in MXNet. I don't want to create an unnecessary object. I looked at this method and it should be static as it doesn't use any member variables to function, this for me is a basic rule of thumb of software engineering, that's pretty much all there is to this PR intention.\

It avoids the creation of this additional object that is not needed. The gradient function is operating on Node and NodePtr, NodeEntry etc as you are well aware. So from a user perspective yes I would like this merged or factored out of this class if you think there's a better place to put this kind of functions, please make a suggestion.

If your request is that I also make ListInputNames or any other similar function static for consistency I'm fine with adding some additional work to keep everything consistent, as I think this would be a fair request.

Regarding discussion, what I was alluding to is a more general and extended discussion about improving the nnvm graph semantics, for example the graph and nodes could be more generic and have attributes as template arguments (think of NodeAttributes). This would be better than we currently have, for example autograd is shoved into the "info" field which is of type "any", you end up losing type information. This is beyond the scope of this PR.

Please let me know how we should move forward, I obviously would like this PR to be merged otherwise I wouldn't have opened it. I'm open to have additional refactorings requested. If it's not merged I will create a symbol as before but I would prefer to avoid that, for me is just a small ramification of a larger refactor.

Thanks.

OK let me try again to summarize the discussions here. I think the API style really has things to do with a different perspective of what defines the graph. 

- The original API's view says that the Symbol object itself defines the graph, and whenever you wanted to create ListInputs, create a temporary Symbol object to do so.
- Your current view says that Graph itself should not be bound to Symbol, and vector<NodeEntry> should be sufficient to define a graph, and thus you want to add the static function.

Both ways are valid engineering points. I personally know very well when should use static method vs member functions. However, even given my pedantic view about the code and infra, I do believe this is a case that could have gone either way. 

Only changing one API ListInputNodes, represent a breach of the consistency of the design -- because of parts of the API goes into one style while rest remains in another.

Given that the historical design has already made an opinionated view about what a symbolic graph should be, I would prefer to keep the API as it is. Creating a temporary object is fine, as one-liner and wouldn't breach anything in the code and it keeps the view of API consistent with the original design. It won't be a critical blocker for your changes.

While I understand sometimes different developer has different points of views and I fully understand potential frustration you might have given your take of design(which was apparently quite clear). Please think a bit more again about the technical points here and see if it the other side of the argument also makes sense.

If I would have to make a recommendation. I would recommend just create a temporary symbol and keep the same perspective as the original design.

I disagree. That means doing an additional copy of the nodes for no reason. Also we are using Node objects constantly, not Symbol.

This is how the refactored code looks like:
 https://github.com/larroy/mxnet/blob/fc_higher_order_grad_2/src/imperative/imperative.cc#L345

About Graph being bound to Symbol, I don't have a strong opinion since I didn't write the original code myself. Actually the change that introduced this call was reviewed by you, so I assume you were supportive of using the graph through Node and NodePtrs and not Symbol:  

https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/pull/7698

After I applied @tqchen 's suggestion, the vectorization error disappeared.

#3131
But I do not have the access to rk3399 right now. Can you verify it @yzhliu ?
@merrymercy @yzhliu @sgrechanik-h @kazum @kevinthesun  please help review this PR
https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/pull/3132 is an attempted improvement to alleviate this situation. In particular, the two cases examples can now be simplified

About Graph being bound to Symbol. I am specifically referring to the ListXYZ API in the Symbol, as all of them now are member functions and treat general List Input manipulation as a special operation to the data structure defined by the symbol.

Performance-wise, the additional copy won't become the bottleneck of your code given that there are already many vector and additional data structure created during PostOrder Visit. And creating the symbol will just be fine. The reason for doing so is to respect the original semantics of ListXYZ as they are bound to the Symbol. 

I think at the moment all the argument has been presented. I have read your refactored code(fully understand what you want and your arguments),  and have presented my recommendation :) This is certainly not perfect,  as everything is part of the tradeoff in software. Just like there are also additional trade-offs you make by using template vs type-erased any (which we could discuss once you brought up the RFC).

I do hope that you can also take a look at the discussion thread and consider it for a while. To me, the code itself is not a big deal, but I do hope we can handle technical debate in a diplomatic fashion.
@merrymercy I tested on the device, it works.

Ok I have addressed most of the issues, except for `unsigned long long` complains cpplint is giving on arguments for DPI functions. The reason why I used this type is because this is the same type used by Verilator when it compiles 64-bit hardware types to C. 

EDIT: I fixed this by creating a type for dpi-arguments and lint-off that. This is easier to modify in the future.

Don't have permissions to add reviewers; could @eqy @jroesch @ZihengJiang @junrushao1994 take a look?
Feel free to suggest other reviewers as well.
Because CUDA and OpenCL backends generate kernel source as C strings, while ROCm backends generates LLVM IR

@antinucleon Actually, most of my tuning results in this failure but not happens in CUDA backend:
```sh
error: local memory limit exceeded (73728) in default_function_kernel0
```
Do you know the solution to this error?

This is not clean, but you can modify [this block](https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py#L231-L241) for rocm target.

```
 if 'cuda' in self.task.target.keys or 'opencl' in self.task.target.keys:
            remote = request_remote(self.key, self.host, self.port)
            ctx = remote.context(str(self.task.target), 0)
            max_dims = ctx.max_thread_dimensions
            kwargs['check_gpu'] = {
                'max_shared_memory_per_block': ctx.max_shared_memory_per_block,
                'max_threads_per_block': ctx.max_threads_per_block,
                'max_thread_x': max_dims[0],
                'max_thread_y': max_dims[1],
                'max_thread_z': max_dims[2],
            }
```

For rocm, max_shared_memory_per_block should be 48KB, and max threads per block should be 256. Don't forget to add "if 'rocm' in self.task.target.keys".

```sh
DEBUG:autotvm:No: 1000  GFLOPS: 0.00/0.00       result: MeasureResult(costs=(InstantiationError('Traceback (most recent call last):\n  [bt] (1) /opt/tvm/build/libtvm.so(TVMFuncCall+0x65) [0x7fc0db08f915]\n  [bt] (0) /opt/tvm/build/libtvm
.so(+0x8f2e8b) [0x7fc0db08be8b]\n  File "/opt/tvm/python/tvm/_ffi/_ctypes/function.py", line 71, in cfun\n    rv = local_pyfunc(*pyargs)\n  File "/opt/tvm/python/tvm/autotvm/measure/measure_methods.py", line 595, in verify_pass\n    rais
e InstantiationError("Skipped because of invalid gpu kernel")\ntvm.autotvm.task.space.InstantiationError: Skipped because of invalid gpu kernel',),), error_no=1, all_cost=0.02058720588684082, timestamp=1557040253.856357)    [('tile_k', [
16, 2, 64]), ('tile_y', [1, 2, 32, 32]), ('tile_x', [1, 1024, 1, 2]), ('auto_unroll_max_step', 1500)],,None,12857110
Too many errors happen in the tuning. Now is in debug mode
WARNING:autotvm:Too many errors happen in the tuning. Now is in debug mode
```
Thanks @merrymercy @tqchen  @eqy @icemelon9 for fixing and reviewing.
Thanks @yongwww

If you specify constraints on shared mem size, number of threads, etc, verify_pass would reject kernel configurations that do not satisfied that constraints (invalid configurations are still considered because of random nature of autotvm). I think the warning you got is the result of rejection. 

As long as autotvm visits configuration that satisfy your constraints, autotvm should be able to make progress.

I also recommend making 'auto_unroll_max_step' smaller. 1500 is too big and causes a pressure on register usage. 125-256 should be good.
@masahi Thanks, I updated this parameter, though I didn't find the tuning result get better.

I'm good with the RFC overall. Slightly prefer `!` same as @MarisaKirisame.
@tqchen can you give another round of review?

re: the precision issue with double backed float literal. My feeling is that as long as the target is machine learning double is more than enough, and we should simply document the behavior and move on for now. It is important to keep the project simple with minimum dependencies.

We could optionally disable constant folding for data types with large bit precision later which will give us similar desirable behavior, or simply send a WARNING to the user. 

re mainline a data type into TVM. I believe the current strategy is really to make new data types pluggable, so we should not make third-party dependency about certain data types for now. Once we are certain, we might consider adding native support, which gives the automatic benefit like GPU kernel generation for free.

Theoretically yes, but we're looking into TVM and TVM handles onnx as input, which lead to the error above. Using another library would just be avoiding a symptom, whereas I'm more a friend of solving problem at its root. Don't get me wrong, I don't want to make accusations, I'm just saying there is room for improvement in terms of robustness in TVM (when it comes to handling (invalid) onnx). Since the [ONNX specification](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/blob/master/docs/IR.md#graphs) states, that the graph is topologically sorted, it would be sufficient for TVM to just reject the ONNX with an error like "This graph is not topologically sorted and thus invalid."
Ok sounds good. We can do it incrementally.
@yongwww what's the status on this?

@zhiics I just merged @antinucleon's PR updating the build function. It looks like there are conflicts, but it would be great to integrate the two. I would like to minimize the amount of time we have two different code paths.
@jroesch I'm on vacation this week, will update the pr to incorporate comments by this weekend

Thanks for the PR. One thing I want to note is that we want to focus on the good use-cases in index simplification. 

- Think about specific index simplification applications
- Collectively use rewrite/canonical simplifier

For example, it is a bit unclear whether taking the gcd out from ```x * c1 + y * c2``` is helpful in a particular case(the canonical does it in another way). Similarly, most of the divisions we encounter in index simplification will rarely have a negative value in the right operand.

To elaborate about the second principle, given that canonical simplifier now inheritates rewrite simplifier, we might be able to use canonical for many cases that rewrite simplifier is not good at.

It would be great if we can provide some justifications for the set of changes.
@srkreddy1238 what is the status of this issue?
As a side note, we can also provide a layout transformation pass to do the layout transformation(from NHWC->NCHW, or NCHW4) in relay.
I will leave the PR management to @icemelon9
Maybe it is caused by creating a bunch of python worker subprocess which results in resource conflicts. How to reduce the number of workers created by TVM?

Will address it in coming weekend.
the ci consistently fails at `./test/scripts/task_cpp_unittest.sh` which I think has nothing to do with this PR right?

@tqchen I'm currently trying to move my implementation of tensor expression autodiff to the new simplifiers instead of the obsolete Halide simplifier. Most of these changes are required for simplifying complex automatically generated expressions involving divisions. Most of the new rules are just slightly modified copies of the existing rules, just to cover more cases.

> For example, it is a bit unclear whether taking the gcd out from `x * c1 + y * c2` is helpful in a particular case(the canonical does it in another way).

It is needed to simplify expressions like `2 * x + 4 * y <= 0`. I think I can move it to the LT case.

> Similarly, most of the divisions we encounter in index simplification will rarely have a negative value in the right operand.

I can remove the corresponding test cases and the rules specifically designed to cover the negative divisor case, since they are not really required by the autodiff. However I would keep them just in case.

> 
> To elaborate about the second principle, given that canonical simplifier now inheritates rewrite simplifier, we might be able to use canonical for many cases that rewrite simplifier is not good at.

The rewrite simplifier has a clear design, so I would prefer fixing the rewrite simplifier rather than the canonical simplifier.


Currently there are CI errors which seem to be connected to the fact that the old Halide notion of division is still in use in some parts of TVM. I didn't expect it and have to think what to do with them.
@jroesch Sure. Let me act on integrating them.

re: precision issue. Agree with moving along with the PR, but we should open an issue discussing the use of arbitrary precision libraries. Since many folks are interested in exploring the question of "reproducible ML", it might make sense to invite contributions on that end; double precision float would be rather limiting in that regard.
you will need to use RPC  mode for Rocm. See https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/apps/rocm_rpc/README.md

I see, thanks for sharing your thoughts! I agree with most of your comment. I do hope that we can move forward to have a combined use case of canonical/rewrite simplifications. Given that canonical can be much more global and will be our default simplifier in the future.

Specifically, the canonical simplifier can aggressively simplify complicated patterns of div/mod which are otherwise hard for rewrite simplifier
I am not convinced that precision beyond double float is necessary for any instance of deep learning model, but we can discuss that perspective in another RFC thread.
